title-group.article-title: Climate-driven fluctuations in freshwater flux to Sermilik Fjord, East Greenland, during the last 4000 years

author-notes.corresp: Sebastian H. Mernild, Climate, Ocean, and Sea Ice Modeling Group, Computational Physics and Methods (CCS-2), Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos NM 87545, USA. Email: mernild@lanl.gov, smernild@gmail.com

abstract.p: The freshwater runoff from the glaciated and snow-covered Sermilik Fjord catchment, SE Greenland, was estimated at annual resolution for the period 1900–2008 and at decadal resolution for the past four millennia. Our simulations were forced with available meteorological station data (1900–2008) and Greenland ice core estimated temperature data (1899 bc–ad 1980) from Dye3 and GISP2. Time series of estimated ice discharge (2000–2009) for the three major outlet glaciers Helheim, Fenris, and Midgård indicate that 53–74% of the ice discharge variations could be explained by variations in areally averaged glacier terminus surface (supraglacial) runoff. Based on these data and together with calculated subglacial geothermal and frictional melting as well as net precipitation for the fjord area, the Sermilik Fjord freshwater flux was deduced for the period 1900–2008. Our simulations indicated that during the last century surface freshwater runoff has equaled 13% of the Sermilik Fjord average freshwater flux of 33.0±5.7×109 m3/yr, covering a periodic runoff variation of 20 years. Ice discharge has accounted for 81%, with 63% of the freshwater flux originated from the Helheim glacier. This indicates that the Helheim outlet glacier plays a dominant role as a freshwater source to both Sermilik Fjord and ultimately the Irminger Sea. For the palaeorecords of the last 4000 years, simulated surface runoff has averaged 4.4±0.2×109 m3/yr. A very weak decreasing trend in runoff over the last 4 k years (1899 bc–ad 1980) is presumably associated with the general insolation-generated Northern Hemisphere cooling since the Holocene Thermal Maximum. Our simulations furthermore indicated centennial- to submillennial-scale variations in surface runoff concurrent with the well-known climate episodes such as the ‘Roman Warm Period’, the ‘Dark Ages Cold Period’, the ‘Medieval Climate Anomaly’, and the ‘Little Ice Age’. During the ‘Little Ice Age’, e.g., the average surface runoff was about 0.7×109 m3/yr lower than today, while the increase in runoff for the Modern Warming, since the late 1800s, was the second strongest and fastest for the last 4 k years.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In addition to the global warming of ~0.7°C since the 1850s (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), 2007), global-mean and Arctic-mean instrumental temperature records show substantial variability on multidecadal to interannual timescales (e.g. Hurrell, 1995; Schlesinger and Ramankutty, 1994). Such fluctuations among others modify the Arctic hydrological cycle (e.g. Hinzman et al., 2005) and cryospheric elements such as the Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS), including its outlet glaciers, marginal glaciers and snow cover, and are useful indicators of present and past climate change, including atmospheric temperature and precipitation, and play a significant role in climate feedback mechanisms such as freshwater supply to the oceans (e.g. ACIA, 2005; Hanna et al. 2008; Howat et al., 2005, 2007; van den Broeke et al., 2009).

In order to understand and predict the impact of a likely shift from present conditions to a future warmer and wetter Arctic climate, it is essential to assess the impact from past short- (annual to multidecadal) and long-term (century to millennia) climate fluctuations. This is the best possible way of gaining knowledge of climate–cryospheric–hydrological interactions and the subsequent contribution of freshwater to the ocean. Unfortunately knowledge and observations of present freshwater runoff to the ocean in the Arctic are sparse, which is a serious impediment to hydrological research efforts. Only few runoff simulations based on climate-driven fluctuations have been estimated and predicted from glaciated and/or snow-covered areas (e.g. Bøggild et al., 1998, 1999; Bruland and Killingtveit, 2002; Bruland and Sand, 1994; Hirashima et al., 2004; Hock, 2003; Mernild et al., 2010a, b). Especially for Greenland, and from the GrIS, runoff is poorly constrained because of a lack of in situ measurements, and there is an urgent need for information on runoff rates. Only a few high-resolution freshwater runoff measurements are available from the east coast of Greenland, e.g. from the Mittivakkat Glacier catchment at Sermilik Fjord (65°N), SE Greenland (Mernild and Hasholt, 2006): Time series of instrumental data, which are important sources of information on runoff rates and variability, allowing for assessment and quantification of the impact of climate changes on freshwater runoff to the ocean.

The Sermilik Fjord is the largest fjord system in SE Greenland draining the largest and most active glacier outlets in SE Greenland; a drainage which may have a significant impact on freshwater output to the North Atlantic. Mernild et al. (2010c) presented an initial study of Sermilik Fjord freshwater flux–ice discharge and runoff, from 1999 to 2008. Here, the work is expanded to a much longer timescale and specifically addressed, in detail, are surface runoff variations and trends from the glaciated and snow-covered Sermilik Fjord, based on both observed meteorological data (1900–2008) and Greenland ice core estimated temperature data from GISP2 and Dye3 (1899 bc–ad 1980).

The goal of the present study is thus to provide information of Sermilik Fjord’s freshwater flux to the ocean and possible variations associated with both short- and long-term climate fluctuations over the past four millennia (the study does not include ocean fluxes). The freshwater flux, including subglacial geothermal and frictional melting due to basal ice motion, is first estimated at annual resolution for the period 1900–2008 based on observed meteorological data and satellite-derived ice discharge (Howat et al., 2005, 2007), to investigate for short-term variability. Second, based on GrIS ice core temperature archives (Langway et al., 1985; Stuiver et al., 1995), surface runoff was estimated for the period 1899 bc–ad 1980 at decadal resolution in order to elucidate possible long-term variability. Our study has thus the following objectives: (1) to estimate the rates, trends, and variations in ice discharge from the three major outlet glaciers: Helheim, Fenris, and Midgård (1900–2008); (2) to quantify the overall freshwater fluxes to the fjord from the different sources: surface runoff, subglacial geothermal and frictional melting due to basal ice motion, ice discharge, and net precipitation for the Sermilik Fjord area, and address whether ice discharge or surface runoff is the dominant flux of freshwater for the period 1900–2008; (3) to test whether climate-driven variations in surface runoff occurred on both longer centennial to millennial timescales and on shorter decadal to multidecadal timescales; (4) to estimate whether the well-known climate events of ‘the Roman Warm Period’, ‘the Dark Ages Cold Period’, ‘the Medieval Climate Anomaly’, the ‘Little Ice Age’ and the twentieth century ‘Modern Warming’ had an impact on glacial melting and surface runoff; and (5) to investigate periodic variations found by simulations, both on short-term annual to decadal scale for 1900–2008, and on long-term multicentury to millennia scale for 1899 bc–ad 1980.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: The approximately 85 km long Sermilik Fjord is the largest fjord system (1103 km2) in SE Greenland (Figure 1a), and it connects the GrIS directly to the Irminger Sea. The Sermilik Fjord catchment (58 045 km2) contains a relatively large portion of the GrIS, the Helheim outlet glacier (one of the most dominant outlet glaciers from the GrIS), and marginal glaciers, including the Mittivakkat Glacier on Ammassalik Island (Figure 1b). The Mittivakkat Glacier is the only marginal glacier in East Greenland where a long-term monitoring program of mass balance and runoff occurs (e.g. Knudsen and Hasholt, 2008; Mernild and Hasholt, 2006; Mernild et al., 2011; World Glacier Monitoring Service (WGMS), 2009). The Sermilik Fjord catchment is located within the wettest/snowiest parts of Greenland: for the meteorological station Tasiilaq (located less than 10 km from the Sermilik Fjord outlet) the mean annual corrected precipitation was ~1200 mm w.eq/yr (corrected after Allerup et al., 1998, 2000), and mean annual air temperature (MAAT) −0.9°C (1900–2008) (Figure 2a and b).

caption.p: (a) Sermilik Fjord area with topography (300 m contour interval) and the Tasiilaq meteorological station; and (b) MODIS satellite-derived surface characteristics (30 August 2009), watershed divide and catchment (58 045 km2), and the location of the three major GrIS outlet glaciers: Helheim, Fenris, and Midgård. The inset figure indicates the general location of the Sermilik Fjord in SE Greenland, and the location of GISP2 (northern diamond), Dye3 (southern diamond) ice cores on the GrIS, and Nuuk meteorological station in SW Greenland (dot)

Time series of atmospheric values from Tasiilaq meteorological station, Sermilik Fjord surface runoff, and Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) for 1900–2008: (a) MAAT anomaly and 10 yr running average; (b) annual corrected precipitation anomaly and 10 yr running average; (c) annual simulated surface runoff anomaly and 10 yr running average; and (d) smoothed and unsmoothed AMO (http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/data/timeseries/AMO/). The baselines time period of the anomalies are 1900–2008. Precipitation was corrected after Allerup et al. (1998, 2000)

sec.title: SnowModel input data and model verification
sec.p: SnowModel is a state-of-the-art spatially distributed meteorological, snowpack, and ice melt modeling system (Liston and Elder, 2006a, b; for a detailed description of SnowModel, including its submodels MicroMet, EnBal, SnowPack, and SnowTran-3D and modifications, see also, e.g. Liston et al., 2008; Mernild and Liston, 2010; Mernild et al., 2006, 2010b) used here to simulate the temporal and spatial surface runoff variability to the Sermilik Fjord. Daily temporal meteorological data were obtained from the station in Tasiilaq (a meteorological station operated by the Danish Meteorological Institute; Figure 1a), spanning the 110 year period from September 1899 through August 2009. The runoff simulations were conducted on one-day time steps. For a description of the user-defined constants, input parameters used in SnowModel such as air temperature lapse rates, digital elevation model (500 m grid increment covering a 400.5 km × 300.5 km domain), vegetation cover (estimated by Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite images; indicating the location of the Sermilik Fjord coast line, GrIS terminus, and marginal glaciers), and model uncertainties see Mernild et al. (2010c) and references therein. Here, it should be kept in mind that changes in glacier cover and land area due to changes in climate and sea level, respectively, throughout the 4 k period have not been taken into account. SnowModel is a surface model producing first-order effects of climate change, and does not include glacier-dynamic, glacio-hydrodynamic and glacio-sliding routines. Therefore, not including changes in glacier cover might cause uncertainties in surface runoff in the range of 10–25% throughout the 4 k period. This is because: (1) glacial depositional landforms indicate that e.g. the Mittivakkat Glacier margins have retreated up to approximately 1.3 km since the maximum extension of the ‘Little Ice Age’ (LIA; ad 1250–1920) (Humlum and Christiansen, 2008); and (2) the discovery of remains of a reindeer antler and peaty material that the glacier cover before the onset of the LIA was close to or smaller than today (Knudsen et al., 2008).

SnowModel simulated runoff was verified (bias corrected) against observed Mittivakkat Glacier catchment runoff (1999–2005) before runoff simulations were conducted for the entire Sermilik Fjord catchment (see Mernild et al., 2010c, for further information).

sec.title: Ice discharge
sec.p: For the three major outlet glaciers Helheim, Fenris, and Midgård in Sermilik Fjord (Figure 1) time series of ice discharge for 1900–2008 were estimated based on significant trends (linear regression; r2=0.68, p<0.01; r2=0.53, p<0.01; and r2=0.74; p<0.01, respectively) between satellite-derived ice discharge and simulated areally averaged annual surface runoff at the glacier terminus for 1999–2008. Areally averaged surface runoff was therefore used as a proxy to calculate iceberg discharge time series, since runoff has an influence on ice discharge because of englacial routing and basal conditions at the GrIS ice–bed interface – conditions caused by the effect of a lubricated interface that causes basal ice to slide over its bed. Between 53% and 74% of the ice discharge fluctuations, for the period 1999–2008, could be explained solely by surface runoff (meltwater), even though variations in ice dynamics (including kinematic waves) and bed topography not have been taken into account.

Time series of ice flux to the calving front (1999–2008), which we term ice discharge, will equal the sum of ice loss to calving and melt at the calving face resulting from incoming deep-ocean heat flow: values which must have a profound influence on grounding-line stability and ice-flow dynamics (Rignot et al., 2010). Ice discharge was calculated from satellite-observed average surface velocity, glacier width, and estimated ice thickness, and assumes to have an error of 15–25% (a detailed description of the satellite-derived ice discharge procedures and errors are described by Howat et al. (2005, 2007) and Mernild et al. (2010c, and the references herein).

sec.title: Geothermal and frictional melting
sec.p: The upper-bounds of geothermal and frictional melting due to basal ice motion were estimated by Mernild et al. (2010c) for the period 1999–2008. We have here used the same procedures for the period 1900–2008. When doing so, it was assumed that all glacier beds below 1200 m a.s.l. were at the melting temperatures (a present day area of ~2300 km2), and influenced by a typical geothermal heat flux of 0.05 W/m2, producing a basal melt rate of 5 mm w.eq/yr (Cuffey and Paterson, 2010), and a geothermally induced runoff rate of 0.01×109 m3/yr. This geothermal runoff rate can be ignored since it is less than 0.05% of the overall freshwater flux to Sermilik Fjord. The maximum rate of frictional melting volume due to basal ice motion was estimated to ~0.5×109 m3/yr (1999–2008), which is 2% of the overall freshwater flux to the fjord. This annual rate was used for the period 1900–2008.

sec.title: Ice Core data from Dye3 and GISP2
sec.p: To reconstruct Sermilik Fjord runoff for the past four millennia, available Greenland ice core oxygen isotope (δ18O) data were used. To minimize pitfalls of connecting time series covering different time periods and having different temporal resolution, we limited our selection of ice cores to those with: (1) annual resolution; and (2) with at least 1000 years of uninterrupted annual data. There are two ice cores satisfying these requirements, the Dye3 annual data covering the time span from 1899 bc to ad 1872 (Langway et al., 1985) and the GISP2 ice core data from ad 818 to ad 1987 (Stuiver et al., 1995). Although the Dye3 location is closer to the Sermilik Fjord, its end date of 1873 does not provide opportunity for a direct calibration using the meteorological station observed temperature data. On the other hand the GISP2 oxygen isotope time series running up to 1987 provides a considerable overlap with the southern Greenland meteorological station temperature data. Our composite temperature time series includes the annual Dye3 δ18O proxy data from 1899 bc to ad 817, and the annual δ18O GISP2 data for the years 818–1987. The dating of ice cores was done by counting the annual layers (Langway et al., 1985; Stuiver et al., 1995). To connect the two time series (GISP2 and Dye3) we normalized the Dye3 data to have the same mean and variance (or standard deviation) as the GISP2 data within a period of overlap from 818–1872.

For calibration purposes (to translate oxygen isotope data to temperature variability) mean annual atmosphere temperature (MAAT) observations from the two coastal meteorological stations were used: Tasiilaq (since 1895), and Nuuk (since 1880) in SW Greenland (Figure 1a). Missing years in the two time series were filled in with average values of the two neighboring years. The MAAT time series within overlapping years (from 1895–2009) were highly correlated, with correlation coefficient r=0.67. MAAT from the two stations provided a 93-year overlap (1895–1987) with the GISP2 oxygen isotope ice core data. The correlation coefficient between the annual GISP2 δ18O data and the MAAT of the two stations (Tasiilaq and Nuuk) is r=0.46, indicating a statistical significance at the 95% level (p<0.05). Thus, there is less than 5% probability that such a correlation between the two time series can be produced by chance. In spite of the differences in location, elevation, and latitude between the GISP2-site and station Tasiilaq and Nuuk, it was assumed that the main processes responsible for Greenland temperature variabilities at these locations are dominated by the same large-scale processes. Consequently we used the GISP2 δ18O record as a proxy for temperature variability of southern Greenland, including the area draining into the Sermilik Fjord, and the GISP2 δ18O anomaly was normalized to the same annual mean and variance as the observed MAAT of the meteorological stations within the overlapping years. It should be noted that ice core estimated MAAT does not take into account local climate variations related to changes in, e.g. topography and glacier cover influencing albedo, and inversions and sea breezes associated with the adjacent and frequently ice-choked fjords and ocean.

sec.title: Surface freshwater runoff for the past few millennia
sec.p: The ice core-estimated MAAT for Southern Greenland, including the Sermilik Fjord, was used as a proxy, together with annual simulated Sermilik Fjord runoff for 1900–1987 (n=88), to calculate (based on a significant linear regression: r2=0.59; p<0.01) the average decadal surface runoff to the Sermilik Fjord for 1899 bc through ad 1980.

sec.title: Climate and surface freshwater runoff (1900–2008)
sec.p: In Figure 2 time series of observed MAAT and corrected recipitation anomalies are illustrated for the period 1900–2008 for Tasiilaq: anomalies calculated compared with the period 1900–2008. The MAAT for this period was −0.9°C and average annual precipitation was ~1200 mm w.eq/yr (Figure 2). Based on a 10-year running average temperature distribution, below average temperatures occurred in the period up to 1920 and for 1960–1998 (Figure 2a). Between 1920 and 1960, and again after 1998, temperatures were above average. Within the period 1900–2008, the 10-year running temperature average illustrate shifts between cold and warm periods, with a maximum difference in running average between coldest and warmest years of ~2°C (for unsmoothed temperature data a maximum difference of ~5°C occurred; Figure 2a), and coinciding with 60–80 years variability of the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO) (Figure 2d) (e.g. Chylek et al., 2009, 2010; Folland et al., 1986; Kerr, 2000; Knudsen et al., 2011; Schlesinger and Ramankutty, 1994).

In contrast, annual temperature variations are presumably linked to year-to-year changes in flow pattern of weather systems (lows) affecting the region, i.e. the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) (Hanna and Cappelen, 2003; Hanna et al., 2008; Hurrell and Deser, 2009; Hurrell, 1995; Portis et al., 2000; Rogers, 1984).

For Tasiilaq, the precipitation is almost in anti-phase with the temperature anomaly (Figure 2a and b); variation in running average showed a maximum difference of ~700 mm w.eq. between driest and wettest years (for unsmoothed precipitation data a maximum difference of ~1900 mm w.eq. occurred; Figure 2b). During relatively dry years at Tasiilaq (precipitation below average), e.g. from 1915 to 1960, the temperature was generally above average, and vice versa (Figure 2a). This pattern may possibly be explained by deep Icelandic lows and may be associated with stronger westerly winds bringing dry but relatively warm air masses to SE Greenland during +NAO scenarios (e.g. Bromwich et al., 1999; Hurrell, 1995; Hurrell and Deser, 2009); this pattern is also linked with strong AMO (Figure 2d).

Surface freshwater runoff to the ocean is a product of both meltwater from melting snow and glacier ice and net precipitation (precipitation minus evaporation), indicating that runoff fluctuations were largely tied to changes in both mean summer temperature (June through August) and annual precipitation. In Figure 2c the 1900–2008 surface runoff variability is shown for Sermilik Fjord. The annual runoff has ranged from 1.4±0.3×109 m3 (1938) to 8.1±1.8×109 m3 (1932) during this period, averaging 4.3±0.7×109 m3/yr. The 1938-runoff minimum may be ascribed to a combination of a relatively cold summer average (5.4°C) and a dry year (~210 mm w.eq.; ~45% came from rain), while the 1932-runoff maximum corresponds to a relatively high summer average (7.9°C), and a wet year (~1440 mm w.eq.; ~75% came from rain) (Figure 2). For the GrIS, retention and refreezing in the snow pack indicate that high runoff years are synchronous with low precipitation/accumulation years. This trend was reported for the whole GrIS by Hanna et al. (2008) and Mernild et al. (2009), as more meltwater was retained in the thicker snowpack, reducing runoff. This effect was most pronounced above the GrIS equilibrium line altitude (ELA; defined as the elevation where surface mass balance, SMB, equals zero), where meltwater does not infiltrate far into the snowpack because of the snowpack’s cold content. At the lower lying Sermilik Fjord catchment area, this trend is less pronounced because of the relatively minor percentages of glacier cover, the relatively minor end-of-winter snow depth, and the less developed end-of-winter snow cold content, minimizing the potential for refreezing in the snow pack.

The 10-year running average anomaly illustrated in Figure 2c shows that surface runoff is a product of combined temperature (surface melt) and precipitation (rain and snow). A spectral analysis indicates a cyclicity with a 20-year periodicity, with a significance level of 65% and with a maximum difference in running average of approximately 1.6×109 m3 between years with greatest and lowest running average runoff (for unsmoothed runoff data a maximum difference of ~6.5×109 m3 occurred; Figure 2c). Here, it should be kept in mind that the analysis is only based on a 110-year time series.

The spatial surface runoff distribution for Sermilik Fjord is shown in Figure 3a and b, for the decade with the average lowest and highest annual runoff of 3.7×109 m3/yr (1980–1989) and 5.0×109 m3/yr (1910–1919), respectively. Those parts of the fjord catchment exhibiting glacier covers at low altitudes, e.g. the Helheim Glacier terminus and the Mittivakkat Glacier showed the highest areally averaged simulated surface runoff (Figure 3a, b). The uneven spatial runoff distribution produced an average minimum and maximum runoff of up to 1.75 m w.eq./yr (1980–1989) and 2.25 m w.eq./yr (1910–1919), respectively, for the Helheim Glacier terminus.

caption.p: (a) Decadal simulated areally averaged minimum surface freshwater runoff (1980–1989) to Sermilik Fjord; and (d) decadal areally average decadal maximum runoff (1910–1919) (data are unfortunately missing from 1910 and 1911)

sec.title: Freshwater flux to Sermilik Fjord (1900–2008)
sec.p: To deduce the overall freshwater flux to Sermilik Fjord, one needs to take into account contributions from surface runoff, ice discharge influenced by GrIS dynamical and sliding processes, seasonal changes in GrIS internal drainage system due to melting, runoff from subglacial geothermal melting and frictional melting due to basal ice motion, submarine melting at tidewater glacier margins due to near-coastal subsurface ocean currents, and precipitation (rain and snow accumulation on sea ice) on the Sermilik Fjord surface area. Here, changes in internal drainage system were excluded from the calculations because of missing data, and probably also insignificant because of the overall freshwater flux. A Sermilik Fjord freshwater study for the period 1999–2008 by Mernild et al. (2010c) found that 11% of the freshwater flux originated from surface runoff, 85% from ice discharge (where 65% came from Helheim, 6% Fenris, and 14% Midgård glaciers), 1% from subglacial geothermal melting and frictional melting due to basal ice motion, and 3% from precipitation on the fjord area. Owing to a lack of palaeodata of sufficiently high resolution, the influence of warm ocean water as described by, e.g. Straneo et al. (2010) cannot yet be taken into account. Future studies of marine sediment cores in Sermilik Fjord could provide such information of oceanographic fluctuations and variations in outlet glacier stability, as for example seen in W Greenland (e.g. Andresen et al., 2010; Seidenkrantz et al., 2007, 2008).

In Figure 4a, estimated time series for 1900–2008 of Helheim, Fenris, and Midgård ice discharge are illustrated, together with satellite-derived ice discharge observations of glacial termina (1999–2008). The estimated annual ice discharge for Helheim varied from 16.8 to 33.8×109 m3, averaging 20.8±3.7×109 m3/yr, Fenris 2.1 to 2.9×109 m3, averaging 2.4±0.5×109 m3/yr, and Midgård 1.0 to 8.7×109 m3, averaging 3.7±0.7×109 m3/yr. Compared with the average estimated Sermilik Fjord freshwater flux of 33.0±5.7×109 m3/yr (Figure 4b), the ice discharge contribution from the three major outlet glaciers was 63%, 7%, and 11%, respectively, indicating that a total of 81% of the freshwater flux came from glacier ice discharge (contributions of ice discharge from minor GrIS outlet glaciers e.g. from the Johan Petersens Fjord close to the outlet to the Irminger Sea have been ignored because of a lack of available data). An average ice discharge value of 81% (1900–2008), was in the same order of magnitude (significant) compared to the mean ice discharge value of 85% for 1999–2008 shown by Mernild et al. (2010c). For Sermilik Fjord the average contribution of simulated surface runoff of 4.3±0.7×109 m3/yr (1900–2008) (Figure 4b), forms 13% of the overall average freshwater flux, precipitation on the fjord 4%, equals to 1.3±0.1×109 m3/yr, and subglacial melting 2%, equals to 0.5×109 m3/yr. It can be concluded that the Sermilik Fjord freshwater flux is highly dominated by ice discharge, especially from the Helheim Glacier (one of the most conspicuous GrIS outlet glaciers), rather than from surface freshwater runoff. Our data also show that freshwater fluxes of the past decade are clearly the highest of the period 1900–2008.

caption.p: (a) Time series of annual estimated ice discharge (open marks) from the three major outlet glaciers: Helheim, Fenris, and Midgård and observed values (closed marks), including error bars for 1900–2008. Note, different scale on the ordinates; and (b) annual time series of ice discharge (from Helheim, Fenris, and Midgård Glaciers), simulated surface runoff, simulated precipitation at the Sermilik Fjord area (1103 km2), and the overall freshwater flux to Sermilik Fjord. Values for subglacial geothermal and frictional melting due to basal ice motion are not displayed individually, but incorporated in the overall freshwater flux. The values averaged ~0.01 and ~0.5 m3×109 per yr, respectively (Mernild et al., 2010c)

sec.title: Climate and surface runoff for the past few millennia
sec.p: The estimated decadally averaged temperature for southern Greenland, including the Sermilik Fjord, for the period 1899 bc to ad 1980 (Figure 5a), based on stable isotope data from selected Greenland ice cores, show variations on both multidecadal and centennial to millennial scales. The decadally averaged temperature ranges from ~−2.3°C (ad 521–530) to ~−0.3°C (1520–1511 bc), averaging ~−1.2±0.3°C for the period (Figure 5a). This temperature range is within the range of present temperature observations from coastal meteorological stations within the fjord (Mernild et al., 2008, 2010c). Although the recent analysis (Chylek et al., 2011) identified prevailing near 20-year periodicity in the Greenland ice cores, the spatial analysis of the 100-year running average temperature variations show no clear systematic long-term (century to millennia) cyclicity in temperature variations. Nevertheless, a general weak cooling trend presumably related to the general insolation-induced Northern Hemisphere cooling since the Holocene Thermal Maximum (e.g. Mayewski et al., 2004) was indicated for these past four millennia, with an overall average air temperature decrease of ~0.3°C (Figure 5a; r2=0.42; p<0.01). The second lowest decadal average temperature was reached about ad 1740, after which the record shows a significant (r2=0.76; p<0.01) average temperature increase of ~0.3°C. Our results are in agreement with recent reconstruction of a 4000 year long temperature record at Greenland Summit (Kobashi et al., 2011).

caption.p: (a) Southern Greenland decadal average temperatures estimated based on GISP2 and Dye3 ice core data for 1899 bc–ad 1980; and (b) Sermilik Fjord simulated average decadal surface runoff for 1899 bc–ad 1980 (due to a linear significant relation between ice core-estimated Southern Greenland MAAT and annual simulated surface runoff to Sermilik Fjord for 1900–1987: r2=0.59). Further, bold lines are shown on the ordinate to illustrate the RWP (approximately 110 bc–ad 430), the DA (approximately 440–910), the MCA (920–1170), the LIA (approximately 1250 to 1920) and the Modern Warming of the early twentieth century. As an example the average LIA runoff is illustrated in (b)

sec.p: Based on these temperature reconstructions, we have calculated a tentative record of surface runoff (Figure 5b). It shows the same general trend in variability with relatively high runoff values during warmer periods and lower rates during colder periods. For the ‘Roman Warm Period’ (RWP; 110 bc–ad 430), the mean temperature was ~0.1°C above average compared with 1899 bc–ad 1980, and the Sermilik Fjord surface runoff ~0.3×109 m3/yr above average. For the ‘Medieval Climate Anomaly’ (MCA; ad 920–1170), temperature and runoff were also respectively, ~0.1°C and ~0.3×109 m3/yr above average. During both the RWP and the MCA maximum average decadal runoff values peaked around 4.7×109 m3/yr, which is around the present average runoff level of 4.6±0.7×109 m3/yr (Mernild et al., 2010c). In contrast, for the ‘Dark Ages Cold Period’ (DA, ad 440–910) and the ‘Little Ice Age’ (LIA, ad 1250–1920) the average temperatures was ~0.2°C below average for both, while runoff was ~0.7×109 m3/yr below average for both, as well (in Figure 5b, the average LIA runoff is illustrated as an example). Greater variations in temperature and runoff were seen for the LIA, compared with both the RWP and MCA. Since the Sermilik Fjord surface runoff was estimated to have a significant linear correlation with the variability in temperature for the southern part of Greenland, the average decadal runoff varied from 3.9 to 4.8×109 m3/yr, averaging 4.4±0.2×109 m3/yr (Figure 5b). As in the temperature reconstruction, no clear systematic long-term periodic variations in runoff could be identified through spectral analysis, but further studies may show the multidecadal cyclicity, which was identified as a strong signal prior to 4000 years BP in the GISP2 δ18O record by Knudsen et al. (2011). The average trend in surface runoff was decreasing by ~1.0×109 m3 throughout the simulation period from 1899 bc to ad 1980. However, the average Sermilik Fjord runoff of 4.6±0.7×109 m3/yr for 2000–2009 was the second highest, following only the average decadal runoff of 4.8×109 m3/yr for the 1520–1511 bc period.

The well-known late-Holocene climate variations seen in large areas of the North Atlantic region are also clearly represented here (Figure 5a). The temperature thus varied between long periods of relatively cold or warm conditions. A general shift to colder values at approximately 3200 yr BP also previously described from the GRIP ice core record by Vinther et al. (2005) concurs with the main onset of the Neoglacial cooling dated to approximately 3200 cal. yr BP in southern Greenland (Funder and Fredskild, 1989). This was associated with colder and drier conditions in southern Greenland (Kaplan et al., 2002), generally less runoff to the ocean (Figure 5b), and with a concurrent southward shift in the oceanic Polar Front, a general reorganization of North Atlantic ocean circulation (e.g. Eiríksson et al., 2000; Jiang et al., 2002; Koç et al., 1993; Seidenkrantz et al., 2007), and colder air temperatures over the North Atlantic (Olsen et al., 2010). The first major, albeit relatively short, cold period at approximately 530–120 bc (Figure 5a) may correspond to the cold event at c. 2700 cal. yr BP, among other associated with cold and dry conditions causing vegetational changes in Eastern Greenland (Wagner et al., 2000), decreasing runoff (Figure 5b), decreased sea-surface temperatures on the North Iceland shelf (Jiang et al., 2002), a decreased of influx of warm subsurface waters to the coast of East Greenland (Jennings et al., 2002) and into the Labrador Sea (Seidenkrantz et al., 2007), and increased ice-rafted debris concentrations in the North Atlantic (Bond et al., 1997). Furthermore, benthic foraminiferal data from a marine sediment core off East Greenland indicate that during DA and LIA the influence of warm, Atlantic-source subsurface water to the East Greenland coastal region may have decreased, allowing an increased influence of Polar Water from the East Greenland Current (Jennings et al., 2002), although sea ice conditions may in fact have been more limited than today (Jensen et al., 2003). The lower runoff probably accounted for some of the explanation for the seemingly relatively low extensive sea ice cover during LIA.

Also, diatom-based sea surface temperature calculations indicate colder, albeit variable conditions on the North Iceland shelf linked to weaker northern branch of the Irminger Current (Jiang et al., 2005) concurrent with an increased influx of subsurface Atlantic-source water (stronger southern branch of the Irminger Current) into the Labrador Sea increased (Seidenkrantz et al., 2007), a climate pattern which is similar to those found under strong-NAO situations (Seidenkrantz et al., 2007, 2009). The comparatively warm periods may be correlated to the RWP, MCA, and the Modern Warming since the 1920s. Although colder than average temperatures continued until the 1920s, the general warming trend at the end of the LIA started already about ad 1740, resulting in a significant (r2=0.76; p<0.01) increase in runoff of 2.6×109 m3 to the Sermilik Fjord. Interestingly, the runoff increase of the Modern Warming since the late 1800s was the second strongest and fastest of the entire 4000 yr long record (Figure 5a).

sec.title: Summary and conclusion
sec.p: Fluctuations in climate modify the Arctic hydrological cycle, including the snow and ice cover, and the freshwater flux for the ocean. Climate-driven fluctuations in simulated freshwater have been quantified, together with freshwater flux – runoff and ice discharge – for 1900–2008, and runoff for 1899 bc–ad 1980 to Sermilik Fjord, SE Greenland. For the period 1900–2008 the mean annual Sermilik Fjord freshwater flux was 33.0±5.7×109 m3/yr, where the Helheim Glacier played an important role as a freshwater source to the fjord, and surface runoff a less important role. Furthermore we show that while mean atmospheric temperature and precipitation seem to be highly governed by the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (Figure 2a, b and d), the short-term interannual surface runoff variations for Sermilik Fjord have a general trend of a 20 yr periodicity (Figure 2c) possibly very weakly correlated to the NAO.

For the 1899 bc–ad 1980 simulated Sermilik Fjord surface runoff, multidecadal variations of the 60–80 yr AMO frequency band seem to dominate (see also Knudsen et al., 2011). It should here be borne in mind that calculations of runoff prior to 1900 are based on δ18O, which also depend on atmospheric temperature. This record may thus show a stronger AMO signal than the instrumental runoff record (Figure 2c). At the same time the absence of a c. 20-yr cyclicity in the runoff record prior to ad1900 may probably be either due to lower sample resolution or overprinting by the 60–80 yr frequency band.

Spectral analysis of the 1899 bc–ad 1980 record could not identify true cyclical, long-term runoff variations. However, millennial- to centennial-scale variations were present as during cooling periods as the ‘Dark Ages Cold Period’ and the ‘Little Ice Age’ both Greenland air temperatures, including at Sermilik Fjord, and surface runoff were below average. The lower runoff accounts for some of the explanation for the seemingly relatively low extensive sea ice cover during the LIA as indicated by diatoms off SE Greenland (Jensen et al., 2003), despite the general increase in the influence of Polar Water.

Our studies thus indicate that surface runoff may account for about 15% of the freshwater influx to the Sermilik Fjord system and ultimately the northwestern North Atlantic. This component of the freshwater supply is highly dependent on atmospheric temperatures and precipitation. Furthermore, the overall pattern of freshwater production and thus also glacier melting seems to a large extent to be governed by the general regional climate development and as melting rates show significant variations over the last four millennia on both multidecadal and centennial–millennial scale. This also underlines the fast response of the marginal areas of the GrIS to climate change, and to is worth noting that the surface runoff has been very high since the start of the Modern Warming, and especially since c. ad 2000, also compared with most previous warm events within our study period.

Increased meltwater outflow may potentially influence the strength of Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) and deep-water formation. However, more importantly on shorter time spans, higher regional sea-surface temperatures caused by increased AMOC and a stronger Irminger Current may significantly increase GrIS melting. In order to predict more accurate time series of ice discharge and freshwater fluxes, the influence from oceanographic variability, especially pulses of warm subsurface Atlantic water as described by Straneo et al. (2010) should thus also be integrated, as such warm-water incursions may potentially severely increase regional GrIS melting. Future studies of marine sediment cores in Sermilik Fjord could provide such information on oceanographic fluctuations and variations in outlet glacier stability, as previously seen in W Greenland (e.g. Andresen et al., 2010; Seidenkrantz et al., 2007, 2008). Such marine observations used together with simulated surface runoff would thus be valuable information, to better understand the processes behind variations in ice discharge, to estimate changes in ice discharge to Sermilik Fjord, and to better understand the linkage between ocean circulation and GrIS stability.

ack.p: We extend special thanks to the anonymous reviewers for their insightful critique of this article. Thanks are given to the Danish Meteorological Institute (DMI) for the use of meteorological data from the AWS in Tasiilaq, and to Byrd Polar Research Center, Ohio State University, for use of satellite-derived ice discharge.

fn.p: This work was supported partly by grants from the Climate Change Prediction Program and the Climate and Environmental Science Program within the US Department of Energy’s Office of Science. Los Alamos National Laboratory is operated under the auspices of the National Nuclear Security Administration of the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC52-06NA25396, and partly by the SEDIMICE project (linking sediments with ice-sheet response and glacier retreat in Greenland), Geocenter Denmark. The study is also a contribution to the TROPOLINK project funded by the Danish Council for Independent Research/Nature and Universe (Grant no. 09-069833/FNU) and the PAST4FUTURE project funded by the EU FP7 (project no. 243908).
